body_html:
Hmm. I did say AMD64 but that was a furphy. The laptop is acutally an x64 being an intel i5 which (apparently) has AVX according to good old wikipedia. BUT if I look I have a i5 460M chip, which intel tells me has Intel® SSE4.1, Intel® SSE4.2 extensions. I am still trying to get my head around it but yes, if AVX is separated to SSE4.1 and 4.2 then my playing with tensorflow is kaput. It the lack of AVX would certainly account for both the docker and pip install attempts failing. Thanks ymodak, I will delete my install of tensorflow and look at other frameworks.
…
On Tue, Nov 6, 2018 at 8:09 AM ymodak ***@***.***> wrote: I suspect that your CPU doesn't support AVX instructions <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions#CPUs_with_AVX> which is a requirement for installing TensorFlow 1.6 and above. — You are receiving this because you authored the thread. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#23520 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABsMK2vMYNEd-jfpaFy1RAvOhQRwRpSLks5usLAMgaJpZM4YOP82> .
body_text:
Hmm.  I did say AMD64 but that was a furphy.

The laptop is acutally an x64 being an intel i5 which (apparently) has AVX
according to good old wikipedia.

BUT if I look I have a i5 460M chip, which intel tells me has Intel®
SSE4.1, Intel® SSE4.2 extensions.  I am still trying to get my head around
it but yes, if AVX is separated to SSE4.1 and 4.2 then my playing with
tensorflow is kaput.

It the lack of AVX would certainly account for both the docker and pip
install attempts failing.

Thanks ymodak, I will delete my install of tensorflow and look at other
frameworks.
…

 I suspect that your CPU doesn't support AVX instructions
 <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions#CPUs_with_AVX>
 which is a requirement for installing TensorFlow 1.6 and above.

body:
Hmm.  I did say AMD64 but that was a furphy.

The laptop is acutally an x64 being an intel i5 which (apparently) has AVX
according to good old wikipedia.

BUT if I look I have a i5 460M chip, which intel tells me has Intel®
SSE4.1, Intel® SSE4.2 extensions.  I am still trying to get my head around
it but yes, if AVX is separated to SSE4.1 and 4.2 then my playing with
tensorflow is kaput.

It the lack of AVX would certainly account for both the docker and pip
install attempts failing.

Thanks ymodak, I will delete my install of tensorflow and look at other
frameworks.


On Tue, Nov 6, 2018 at 8:09 AM ymodak <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I suspect that your CPU doesn't support AVX instructions
> <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions#CPUs_with_AVX>
> which is a requirement for installing TensorFlow 1.6 and above.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/23520#issuecomment-436043912>,
> or mute the thread
